data.value: We share neighboring zones between blocks of the array, map a function, and then trim away the neighboring strips. If depth is larger than any chunk along a particular axis, then the array is rechunked.
Note that this function will attempt to automatically determine the output array type before computing it, please refer to the
keyword argument in
if you expect that the function will not succeed when operating on 0-d arrays.
The function to apply to each extended block. If multiple arrays are provided, then the function should expect to receive chunks of each array in the same order.

The number of elements that each block should share with its neighbors If a tuple or dict then this can be different per axis. If a list then each element of that list must be an int, tuple or dict defining depth for the corresponding array in
args
. Asymmetric depths may be specified using a dict value of (-/+) tuples. Note that asymmetric depths are currently only supported when
is 'none'. The default value is 0.

data.param: depth: int, tuple, dict or list

data.value: How to handle the boundaries. Values include 'reflect', 'periodic', 'nearest', 'none', or any constant value like 0 or np.nan. If a list then each element must be a str, tuple or dict defining the boundary for the corresponding array in
args
. The default value is 'reflect'.

data.param: boundary: str, tuple, dict or list

data.value: Whether or not to trim
elements from each block after calling the map function. Set this to False if your mapping function already does this for you

Whether or not to align chunks along equally sized dimensions when multiple arrays are provided.  This allows for larger chunks in some arrays to be broken into smaller ones that match chunk sizes in other arrays such that they are compatible for block function mapping. If this is false, then an error will be thrown if arrays do not already have the same number of blocks in each dimension.
Other keyword arguments valid in
Map a function over blocks of arrays with some overlap
The
function can also accept multiple arrays.
When multiple arrays are given, they do not need to have the same number of dimensions but they must broadcast together. Arrays are aligned block by block (just as in
) so the blocks must have a common chunk size.  This common chunking is determined automatically as long as
is True.

by default.  A non-zero
must be defined for any overlap to appear in the arrays provided to
